newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Vladivostok expects 20,000 T U.S. wheat next month.
newsitem.headline: Vladivostok expects 20,000 T U.S. wheat next month.

text.p: Russia's far eastern port of Vladivostok said on Tuesday it expects to unload 20,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat in November, and a top transport source said total deliveries of U.S wheat to the port could top 100,000 tonnes.
Vyacheslav Pertsev, vice-president of the Vladivostok Commercial Port, said that the facility had issued a preliminary confirmation to unload 20,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat next month.
"We are expecting a transit lot of 20,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat in November," he said. He did not know the quality or price of the grain.

Tatyana Konko, director of the Vladivostok-based Vladvneshtrans transport company, said that she thought the 20,000-tonne delivery was the first of a total of at least 100,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat to be purchased by a grain buying agency in the far east city of Khabarovsk.
"It is my understanding that a U.S. company will supply at least 100,000 tonnes of wheat to the Khabarovsk Bread-products Agency," she said.
Sources said that Konko was probably referring to the regional office of Moscow-based Roskhleboprodukt, the semi-state grain-buying agency.

Konko said that her company would deliver the 20,000-tonne lot to Khabarovsk, from which it would be sent to other Russian regions. Khabarovsk lies about 700 km (450 miles) north of Vladivostok on the Amur River.
Russia has said that it is cheaper to import grain from North America or Australia than to drag domestic grain by rail across its own vast territory.
